TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE

I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.  Analysis of Key Issues 
 
1.  Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have an important role in trade, contributing 
significantly to economic growth and job creation. However, a substantial gap exists in their 
access to financing. The Trade Finance Gaps, Growth and Job Survey published in October 2021 
showed a global trade finance gap of $1.7 trillion in 2020, with more than 40% of rejected trade 
finance transactions coming from SMEs.1 The gap has grown over the course of the coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) pandemic, rising from $1.5 trillion in 2018, and is likely increasing further as 
inflation raises the value of transactions, thereby lowering the ability of existing country and 
counterparty financing limits to meet demand.  
 
2.  The gap is exacerbated by a lack of capacity on the part of both SMEs and local banks to 
provide supply chain finance. SMEs have difficulty accessing supply chain finance for a variety of 
reasons.  Banks generally consider them to have a higher risk profile, more difficult to serve, and 
involve higher transaction costs. Moreover, there is a lack of understanding among SMEs and 
banks on how supply chain finance works and its benefits. Supply chain finance can provide more 
timely access to working capital from financial institutions at more reasonable rates for SMEs not 
served by traditional bank financing since it leverages the strength of a larger corporate entity and 
incorporates the history of performance and interdependence of relationships between it and 
SMEs within a supply chain.  
 
3.  The Trade and Supply Chain Finance Program (TSCFP) works with partner financial 
institutions (PFIs) to close financing gaps of SMEs. TSCFP is composed of the Supply Chain 
Finance Program  (SCFP)  and  the Trade Finance Program  (TFP)  which  were  operationally 
merged in 2020. Whereas TFP takes bank risk to support cross border trade, SCFP shares 
corporate risk with partner financial institutions to support both domestic and cross-border supply 
chains.  While  TFP  has  scaled  into  one  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  largest 
businesses–in 2020, TFP supported over 7,000 transactions valued at $5.8 billion–the SCFP is 
small but growing rapidly. Merging these two businesses is helping SCFP scale up by leveraging 
off  TFP’s  existing  relationships  and  experience,  while  achieving  operational  efficiency  and 
delivering even better client service. 
 
4.  The SCFP arm of TSCFP was established in November 2012 with a limit of $200 million 
to support trade and broaden the financing instruments offered to SMEs for accessing working 
capital.2 In March 2018, the program expanded both in terms of its program limit and its scope 
when additional financing of $100 million was approved, increasing the total program limit to $300 
million.3 SCFP operates in 10 of ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs) and has seen rapid 
growth recently. In 2020, SCFP supported 1,447 transactions, an increase of 151% from the 
previous year, with the overall transaction value increasing 108% to $246 million.   
 
5.  To further reduce SME financing gaps and as a response to strained supply chains 
brought about by the pandemic throughout Asia, including for companies that manufacture and 
distribute food products, medical products, and equipment, the SCFP in June 2021 received 
approval to incorporate on a permanent basis the COVID-19 specific scope changes it was

temporarily allowed to under the ADB’s Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic.4 
The mainstreaming of these changes will (i) broaden private sector support for supply chain 
finance and working capital facilities, (ii) improve cash flows to DMC companies to enable growth 
and job creation, and (iii) produce a demonstration effect that will encourage financial institutions 
to undertake more supply chain financing. 5 
 
6.  Closing SME finance gaps delivers significant development impact by furthering growth 
and job creation and therefore reducing poverty. The proposed TA cluster will build on the ongoing 
work under the previous SCFP TA Cluster6 to continue implementing and expanding SCFP in 
view of the continuation and expansion of special policy variations under ADB’s COVID-19 
response approved in June 2021 (footnote 5). An important element of the TA cluster, and a 
feature that also distinguishes SCFP from TFP, concerns its focus on assessing and monitoring 
SME and corporate risk, and support of open account payment terms. ADB needs to enhance its 
experience and resources in assessing and monitoring this risk, which impedes its ability to 
implement projects directly impacting DMC SMEs. The TA cluster will fund the engagement of 
consultants who will focus on obligor risk assessments, relationship management, program 
administration, transaction processing and portfolio management to support SCFP operations. 
While the primary beneficiary of the TA will be DMC companies, an ancillary beneficiary will be 
ADB itself. ADB’s own technical capacity in working with DMC companies will be enhanced and 
this will position ADB to consider and implement new SME-supportive projects in the future.  
 
7.  Since supply chain finance is relatively new or does not materially exist in some markets, 
continued capacity building and knowledge-sharing events are important to support both the 
growth of this product line and SCFP. The TA cluster will undertake activities related to capacity 
development for DMC banks to develop supply chain finance business models, with a view to 
subsequently signing risk-sharing agreements with these banks to include them as  partner 
financial institutions (PFIs). As the program also aims to play a stronger role in addressing gender 
equality constraints in supply chains, this TA cluster will enhance SCFP’s ability to deliver “gender 
lens” financing capacity building and training to improve banks’ customer service to female 
clientele. 
 
8.  The proposed TA cluster is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030.7 It provides support to 
SCFP which facilitates trade and investment by strengthening the capacity of domestic financial 
institutions  to  encourage  and  expand  access  to  banking  and  financial  services  in  DMCs 
(Operational Priority 7).  It has a demonstration effect on non-partner financial institutions that are 
not yet providing supply chain finance. It likewise tackles Operational Priority 1: Addressing 
Remaining Poverty and Reducing Inequalities Pillar 2 Quality Jobs Generated by providing 
greater access to finance for SMEs in DMCs and helps to create jobs, stimulate growth and 
improve livelihoods. Through SCFP’s promotion of gender equality in banking by facilitating 
training and workshops to female bank staff in DMCs, the TA cluster supports Operational Priority 
2.  
 
9.  Inclusive finance is one of the three pillars of ADB’s Financial Sector Operational Plan, 
which was reaffirmed in its 2017 review.8 One component of the strategic focus of ADB’s Private

B.  Justification for Cluster Modality 
 
10.  The transaction TA cluster will provide capacity building support to continue activities 
undertaken under the first SCFP TA approved in 20139 and subsequent TA cluster approved in 
201810 by engaging consultants to assist in the expansion of the program and implementation of 
pipeline deals over the next 3 years. In addition, capacity development towards DMC bank 
implementation of supply chain finance will be deployed. A cluster modality has been adopted for 
the TA because it: (i) provides an opportunity to conduct financial analyses and diagnostics over 
a longer period without tying down the entire TA resource requirements at the outset; (ii) allows 
the TA to be more responsive to the needs of banks by enabling an annual “repeat engagement” 
approach that builds on the analysis and benchmarks derived during the previous year; and (iii) 
will reduce processing costs compared to individual standalone TA projects.  
 
C.  Outcome and Outputs 
 
11.  Overall outcome. The TA cluster’s overall outcome will be expanded uptake of supply 
chain finance in DMCs. It will help strengthen the capacity of domestic financial institutions to 
encourage and expand access to banking, insurance, and financial services for all, thereby 
meeting an important sustainable development goal.11 Through a combination of knowledge 
 
products, loans, guarantees, and funded and unfunded risk participations, DMC SMEs and 
corporates will receive more financing and PFIs can leverage ADB’s participation to broaden their 
supply chain finance portfolios. This will be measured in terms of the program’s increase in the 
number and value of supply chain transactions. Each TA subproject will generally deliver some 
or all the following outputs, as specified by each transaction TA subproject proposal:  
 
12.  Output 1: Capacity to provide supply chain support through SCFP partner banks 
enhanced. This will be measured based on: (i) the increase in the number of countries in which 
the program is active; and (ii) increase in number of supported transactions involving SMEs. The 
TA cluster will enable ADB to continue to engage consultants who will assist in the implementation 
of the program by: (i) conducting in-depth due diligence and risk analyses on DMC companies, 
including SMEs in which ADB would assume risk under the program, (ii) administering SCFP 
transactions, and (iii) performing monitoring assessments on DMC companies, DMC banks and 
PFIs. 
 
13.  Output 2: Support of gender-inclusive supply chain finance expanded. This will be 
measured based on: (i) the increase in number of DMC banks introducing or expanding supply 
chain finance products, (ii) percentage (at least 50%) of DMC banks participating in SCFP’s 
technical assistance receiving gender lens financing12 capacity building, (iii) institutional capability 
to record sex-disaggregated data introduced in the ADB cofinanced Supply Chain Finance 
Platform for selected DMC banks13, (iv) increase in the number of large global banks participating

14.  Output 3: Bank staff training in supply chain finance and gender balance expanded. 
This will be measured based on: (i) increase in number of bank staff in DMCs participating in 
online or in-person capacity building activities in relation to supply chain finance (of which at least 
30% should be women14); and (ii) percentage (at least 50%) of DMC banks participating in SCFP’s 
technical assistance receiving training focused on improving banks’ customer service to female 
clientele15. The TA cluster will fund related knowledge-sharing and partnership activities including 
seminars, webinars, in-person and/or online trainings for DMC banks on the functions and 
benefits of supply chain finance, how it works and how to attract financing, to help them initiate 
supply chain finance services, including enhancing customer service to female clientele as well 
as on issues related to SME financing such as anti-money-laundering and sustainability. 
 
D.  Cost and Indicative Financing 
 
15.  The TA cluster is estimated to cost $4,500,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF – donor contribution and/or TASF – income 
transfer).  
 
16.  The TA cluster will cover remuneration, travel and per diem for international consultants 
and  national  consultants,  conference-related  expenditures,  and  miscellaneous  expenses. 
Detailed cost estimates and financing arrangements will be presented in each TA subproject 
proposal submitted for approval. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA cluster. Each TA subproject proposal will be submitted for 
approval to the Director General of the Private Sector Operations Department in accordance with 
the business process for transaction TA cluster processing. Subproject activities will start only 
after the project concept for the corresponding ensuing project is approved by ADB.

also  be  recruited  to  provide  international  and  national  consulting  inputs  for  relationship 
management, and program implementation and administration. ADB will organize knowledge 
dissemination training and workshops in various DMCs to facilitate a common understanding of 
supply chain finance products and techniques, including financial technology, and to share 
industry  best  practices,  as  well  as  for  sustainability  and  anti-money-laundering  initiatives. 
Resource persons will be engaged for such seminars, training, and other capacity building 
initiatives. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time) and the associated project administration and/or staff instructions. 
The estimated cost and requisite fields of expertise are indicative, and estimates will be finalized 
prior to approval of each TA subproject.

II.  PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $4,500,000.00 on a grant basis 
for the Capacity Development for the Supply Chain Finance Program (Phase 3), and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
